name: Phenylephrine
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? Phenylephrine is used to relieve nasal discomfort caused by colds, allergies, and hay fever, and to ease sinus congestion and pressure. It reduces symptoms but does not treat the underlying cause or speed recovery. Phenylephrine is a nasal decongestant that works by shrinking swollen blood vessels in the nasal passages. How should this medicine be used? Phenylephrine is taken by mouth as a tablet, liquid, or orally dissolving strip. It is usually taken every 4 hours as needed. Follow the directions on your prescription or package label exactly, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. Do not take more or less than directed or use it more often than recommended. Phenylephrine is available alone or in combination with other ingredients; ask your doctor or pharmacist which product is best for your symptoms. Carefully check labels before using two or more cough and cold products together; many contain the same active ingredients, and taking them together could cause an overdose. This is especially important for children. Nonprescription cough and cold combination products, including those with phenylephrine, can cause serious side effects or death in young children. Do not give these products to children younger than 4 years old. If you give them to children 4 to 11 years old, use caution and follow package directions exactly. If you are giving phenylephrine or a combination product with phenylephrine to a child, read the label to be sure it is appropriate for the child’s age. Do not give adult formulations to children. Before dosing a child, check the label’s age-based dosing chart and give the recommended dose; ask the child’s doctor if you are unsure. If using the liquid, measure doses with the provided device or a medication-measuring spoon or cup, not a household spoon. Stop phenylephrine and call your doctor if your symptoms do not improve within 7 days or if you develop a fever. For dissolving strips, place one strip on your tongue and allow it to dissolve. Other uses for this medicine This medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. What special precautions should I follow? Before taking phenylephrine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to phenylephrine, any other medications, or any ingredients in phenylephrine products. Do not take phenylephrine if you are taking, or have taken within the past 2 weeks, a monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitor such as isocarboxazid (Marplan), phenelzine (Nardil), selegiline (Eldepryl, Emsam, Zelapar), or tranylcypromine (Parnate). Tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. Tell your doctor if you have or have ever had high blood pressure, diabetes, difficulty urinating due to an enlarged prostate, thyroid disease, or heart disease. Tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking phenylephrine, call your doctor. If you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking phenylephrine. If you have phenylketonuria (PKU), be aware that some phenylephrine products may be sweetened with aspartame, a source of phenylalanine. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your normal diet. What should I do if I forget a dose? This medication is usually taken as needed. If your doctor has told you to take phenylephrine on a regular schedule and you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. If it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular dosing schedule. Do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. What side effects can this medication cause? Phenylephrine may cause side effects. Some side effects can be serious. If you experience any of the following, stop using phenylephrine and call your doctor: nervousness, dizziness, or trouble sleeping. Phenylephrine may cause other side effects.

name: Pyrethrin and Piperonyl Butoxide Topical
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? Pyrethrin and piperonyl butoxide shampoo is used to treat lice—small insects that attach to the skin on the head, body, or pubic area ('crabs')—in adults and in children 2 years of age and older. Pyrethrin and piperonyl butoxide is in a class of medications called pediculicides and works by killing lice. How should this medicine be used? Pyrethrin and piperonyl butoxide comes as a shampoo to apply to the skin and hair. It is usually used in two or three treatments; the second treatment must be applied 7 to 10 days after the first, and a third treatment may be recommended by your doctor if needed. Follow the directions on your prescription or package label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. Use pyrethrin and piperonyl butoxide shampoo exactly as directed; do not use more or less or use it more often than instructed. The package label estimates how much shampoo you need based on hair length; be sure to use enough to cover all of your scalp and hair. Use only on the skin or on the hair and scalp. Avoid the eyes, nose, mouth, and vagina. Do not use on eyebrows or eyelashes. If the shampoo gets in your eyes, flush with water right away; if irritation persists after rinsing, call your doctor or seek medical help immediately. To use: Shake the bottle well right before use. Cover your face and eyes with a towel and keep your eyes closed during treatment; an adult may need to help with application. Apply the shampoo to dry hair and scalp or to affected skin. For head lice, start behind the ears and at the back of the neck, then cover all hair and scalp. Leave on for 10 minutes—no longer—and use a timer or clock to track the time. After 10 minutes, add a small amount of warm water to form a lather and shampoo as usual, then rinse hair, scalp, or skin thoroughly with warm water. For head lice, towel-dry the hair, comb out tangles, and consider using a lice comb to remove dead lice and nits (empty egg shells); an adult may need to help. Repeat the entire process in 7 to 10 days to kill lice that hatch from eggs. After treatment, sanitize recently used clothing, underwear, pajamas, hats, sheets, pillowcases, and towels by washing in very hot water or dry-cleaning. Wash combs, brushes, hair clips, and other personal care items in hot water. Ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer’s patient information. Other uses for this medicine This medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. What special precautions should I follow? Before using pyrethrin and piperonyl butoxide shampoo, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to pyrethrin, piperonyl butoxide, chrysanthemums, ragweed, any other medications, or any ingredients in the shampoo; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. Tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. Tell your doctor if you have or have ever had skin conditions. If you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding, tell your doctor. If you become pregnant while using this shampoo, call your doctor. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. What should I do if I forget a dose? It is important to repeat treatment 7 to 10 days after the first application. If you miss the second treatment, call your doctor to discuss your treatment schedule. What side effects can this medication cause? Pyrethrin and piperonyl butoxide shampoo may cause side effects. Tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: itching of the skin or scalp; redness of the skin or scalp. Some side effects can be serious. Call your doctor immediately if you experience trouble breathing, continued irritation of the skin or scalp, or infected or pus-filled areas of the skin or scalp. Pyrethrin and piperonyl butoxide shampoo may cause other side effects.

name: Antipyrine-Benzocaine Otic
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? Antipyrine and benzocaine otic is used to relieve ear pain and swelling from middle ear infections and may be used with antibiotics. It is also used to soften and help remove a buildup of earwax. Both ingredients are analgesics that work together to reduce ear pain and discomfort. How should this medicine be used? Antipyrine and benzocaine otic is a liquid ear-drop solution for use in the ears only. For pain relief, use the prescribed number of drops every 1 to 2 hours as needed. For earwax removal, use the drops 3 times daily for 2 to 3 days. Follow the directions on your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. To apply: warm the bottle in your hand for 1 to 2 minutes; place the prescribed number of drops into the affected ear without touching the dropper tip to the ear, fingers, or any surface; moisten a small piece of cotton with the drops and place it in the outer ear; repeat for the other ear if instructed. Other uses for this medicine This medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. What special precautions should I follow? Before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to antipyrine, benzocaine, or any other medications, or if you have had reactions to topical anesthetics. Tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use. Do not use if you have a hole in your eardrum or ear tubes unless your doctor tells you to. Use only in the ear; do not swallow or use in the eyes. If you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, discuss use with your doctor; call your doctor if you become pregnant while using this medicine. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. What should I do if I forget a dose? This medication is usually used as needed. If your doctor has told you to use it on a regular schedule and you miss a dose, apply it as soon as you remember; if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. Do not use extra drops to make up for a missed dose. What side effects can this medication cause? Antipyrine and benzocaine otic may cause side effects such as mild, temporary burning, stinging, or irritation in the ear. Stop use and call your doctor right away if you have worsening ear pain, new ear drainage, rash, dizziness, trouble breathing, or signs of an allergic reaction.

name: Hydrocortisone Injection
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? Hydrocortisone injection is used to treat symptoms of low corticosteroid levels (lack of certain substances normally produced by the body and needed for normal function) and to treat severe allergic reactions. It is also used in the management of multiple sclerosis, lupus, gastrointestinal diseases, and certain types of arthritis, as well as conditions affecting the blood, skin, eyes, nervous system, thyroid, kidneys, and lungs. Hydrocortisone injection is a corticosteroid. It works by replacing steroids that the body typically makes on its own when levels are low and, for other conditions, by reducing swelling and redness and by modifying immune system activity. How should this medicine be used? Hydrocortisone injection comes as a powder to be mixed with liquid and is given intramuscularly (into a muscle) or intravenously (into a vein). The dosing schedule depends on your condition and response to treatment. It may be administered in a hospital or clinic, or you may be instructed to use it at home. If using it at home, your healthcare provider will teach you how to prepare and inject the medication; be sure you understand the directions and ask questions if anything is unclear. Ask your provider what to do if you have problems using the injection. Your doctor may change your dose during treatment to ensure you are using the lowest effective dose and may adjust it if you experience physical stress (such as surgery, illness, or infection) or if your symptoms change. This medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. What special precautions should I follow? Before receiving hydrocortisone injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to hydrocortisone, other medications, benzyl alcohol, or any ingredients in the product; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. Tell them about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. Nonprescription products that may interact include aspirin and NSAIDs such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) and naproxen (Aleve). Do not start these while receiving hydrocortisone without discussing with your healthcare provider. Do not use hydrocortisone injection if you have a systemic fungal infection (other than on the skin or nails). If you have idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), your doctor will probably avoid intramuscular injections. Tell your doctor if you have or have ever had tuberculosis; cataracts; glaucoma; Cushing’s syndrome; diabetes; high blood pressure; heart failure; a recent heart attack; emotional problems, depression, or other mental illness; myasthenia gravis; osteoporosis; seizures; ulcers; or liver, kidney, heart, intestinal, or thyroid disease; and if you have any untreated bacterial, parasitic, or viral infection or a herpes eye infection. Tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while receiving hydrocortisone. If you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the surgeon or dentist that you are receiving hydrocortisone. Do not receive vaccinations without talking to your doctor. Hydrocortisone may decrease your ability to fight infection and can mask infection symptoms; avoid people who are sick, wash your hands often, and stay away from anyone with chickenpox or measles. Call your doctor right away if you think you were exposed to chickenpox or measles. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Your doctor may recommend a low-salt diet or a diet higher in potassium or calcium and may prescribe calcium or potassium supplements. Follow these instructions carefully. What should I do if I forget a dose? If you self-inject and miss a dose, use it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose; if so, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. Do not use two doses at once. If you miss an appointment for an injection, call your doctor or clinic to reschedule and to receive dosing guidance. What side effects can this medication cause? Hydrocortisone injection may cause side effects. Tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: headache; dizziness; slowed healing of cuts and bruises; acne; thin, fragile, or dry skin; red or purple blotches or lines under the skin; skin depressions at the injection site; increased body fat or fat redistribution; difficulty falling or staying asleep; inappropriate happiness (euphoria); extreme mood or personality changes; extreme tiredness; depression; increased sweating; muscle weakness; joint pain; irregular or absent menstrual periods; increased appetite; hiccups. Some side effects can be serious. Call your doctor immediately if you have: sore throat, fever, chills, cough, or other signs of infection; seizures; vision problems; swelling of the eyes, face, lips, tongue, throat, arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; stomach swelling or pain; difficulty breathing or swallowing; shortness of breath; sudden weight gain; rash; hives; itching; or abnormal patches in the mouth, nose, or throat. Hydrocortisone injection may slow growth in children; your child’s doctor will monitor growth. Long-term use may increase the risk of glaucoma or cataracts; ask your doctor how often to have eye exams. Hydrocortisone injection may increase the risk of osteoporosis. This medication may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience any unusual problems while using it.

name: Methylprednisolone Injection
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? Methylprednisolone injection is a corticosteroid used to treat severe allergic reactions; to help manage multiple sclerosis, lupus, certain gastrointestinal diseases, and some forms of arthritis; and to treat disorders affecting the blood, skin, eyes, nervous system, thyroid, kidneys, and lungs. It may be combined with other medicines to treat symptoms caused by low corticosteroid levels. It replaces natural steroids when your body does not make enough and also reduces swelling and redness by altering immune activity. It is also sometimes used to control nausea and vomiting from certain cancer chemotherapies and to help prevent organ transplant rejection. Talk with your doctor about the risks of using it for these or any other uses. How should this medicine be used? Methylprednisolone injection comes as a powder that is mixed with liquid and given into a muscle (intramuscularly) or into a vein (intravenously). It also comes as a suspension for injection that can be given into a muscle, a joint (intra‑articularly), or directly into a lesion (intralesionally). Your dose and schedule depend on your condition and response. You may receive doses in a clinic or hospital, or you may be taught to give it at home. If using it at home, have your healthcare provider show you exactly how to prepare and inject it, and ask questions until you are confident. Ask what to do if you have any problems using it. Your doctor may adjust your dose over time to the lowest amount that controls your symptoms, and may change your dose during times of physical stress (such as surgery, illness, or infection). Tell your doctor if your symptoms improve, worsen, or if your health changes during treatment. What special precautions should I follow? Before receiving methylprednisolone injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to methylprednisolone, any other medicines, benzyl alcohol, or any ingredients in the product; ask your pharmacist for an ingredient list. Tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. Doses may need adjustment and you may need monitoring for side effects. Over‑the‑counter aspirin and other NSAIDs (such as ibuprofen and naproxen) can interact with methylprednisolone; tell your doctor if you use them, and do not start them while on methylprednisolone without medical advice. Do not use methylprednisolone if you have a fungal infection that is not limited to the skin or nails. If you have idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), your doctor will generally avoid giving methylprednisolone by intramuscular injection. Tell your doctor if you have or have ever had tuberculosis; cataracts; glaucoma; Cushing’s syndrome; diabetes; high blood pressure; heart failure; a recent heart attack; mood or mental health problems (including depression); myasthenia gravis; osteoporosis; seizures; ulcers; or liver, kidney, heart, intestinal, or thyroid disease. Also inform your doctor if you have any untreated bacterial, parasitic, or viral infection anywhere in your body, or a herpes infection of the eye. Tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. If you become pregnant while using methylprednisolone, call your doctor. If you are having any surgery, including dental procedures, tell the surgeon or dentist you are receiving this medication. Do not receive vaccinations without talking to your doctor. This medicine can reduce your ability to fight infection and may mask signs of infection. Avoid people who are sick, wash your hands frequently, and avoid contact with anyone who has chickenpox or measles. Call your doctor right away if you think you have been exposed. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Your doctor may advise a low‑salt diet or a diet higher in potassium or calcium, and may prescribe calcium or potassium supplements. Follow these instructions carefully. What should I do if I forget a dose? If you miss a dose, follow the plan given by your doctor. If you self‑inject on a schedule, take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose; if so, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. Do not inject two doses at once. If you receive injections at a clinic or for a specific treatment cycle, call your healthcare provider to reschedule. What side effects can this medication cause? Methylprednisolone injection may cause side effects. Tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: headache; dizziness; slow healing of cuts and bruises; acne; thin, fragile, or dry skin; red or purple blotches or lines under the skin; a small depression at the injection site; increased body fat or fat redistribution; trouble sleeping; feelings of unusual well‑being (euphoria); mood or personality changes; extreme tiredness; depression; increased sweating; muscle weakness; joint pain; irregular or missed menstrual periods; increased appetite; hiccups. Some side effects can be serious. Call your doctor right away or get emergency help if you have: sore throat, fever, chills, cough, or other signs of infection; seizures; vision problems; swelling of the eyes, face, lips, tongue, throat, arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; trouble breathing or swallowing; shortness of breath; sudden weight gain; rash, hives, or itching; confusion; unusual patches or sores in the mouth, nose, or throat; numbness, burning, or tingling in the face, arms, legs, feet, or hands. Children may grow more slowly while using this medicine; your child’s doctor will monitor growth. Long‑term use may increase the risk of glaucoma or cataracts—ask your doctor how often you should have eye exams. This medicine may also raise your risk of osteoporosis. Methylprednisolone injection may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using it.

name: Chlordiazepoxide
instructions: Important warning: Chlordiazepoxide can increase the risk of serious or life-threatening breathing problems, profound sedation, coma, and death when used with opioid medicines for cough or pain. Examples include codeine (Triacin-C, Tuzistra XR, Fiorinal), hydrocodone (Anexsia, Norco, Zyfrel), oxycodone (Oxycet, Percocet, Roxicet), morphine (Astramorph, Duramorph PF, Kadian), fentanyl (Actiq, Duragesic, Subsys), hydromorphone (Dilaudid, Exalgo), meperidine (Demerol), methadone (Dolophine, Methadose), and tramadol (Conzip, Ultram, Ultracet). Your doctor may need to change doses and will monitor you carefully. Seek emergency help right away if you develop unusual dizziness, lightheadedness, extreme sleepiness, slow or difficult breathing, or unresponsiveness. Ensure caregivers know these symptoms. Chlordiazepoxide may be habit forming. Do not take larger or more frequent doses or use it longer than prescribed. The risk of serious, life-threatening side effects increases if you drink alcohol, use street drugs, or overuse prescription medicines; do not use alcohol or street drugs during treatment. If you have or have ever had depression or another mental illness, tell your doctor. Physical dependence may occur, and stopping suddenly can worsen your condition and cause withdrawal that may last weeks to more than 12 months. Do not stop or reduce your dose without medical guidance; your doctor will taper your dose. Call your doctor or get emergency help if you have withdrawal symptoms such as unusual movements, ringing in the ears, anxiety, memory problems, difficulty concentrating, sleep problems, seizures, shaking, muscle twitching, changes in mental health, depression, burning or prickling in the hands, arms, legs, or feet, seeing or hearing things others do not, thoughts of harming yourself or others, overexcitement, or losing touch with reality. Why is this medication prescribed? Chlordiazepoxide is used to relieve anxiety and to control agitation due to alcohol withdrawal. It is a benzodiazepine that works by decreasing abnormal electrical activity in the brain. It may also be prescribed for irritable bowel syndrome; discuss risks and benefits with your doctor. How should this medicine be used? Chlordiazepoxide comes as tablets or capsules taken by mouth, usually one to four times daily, with or without food. Take it exactly as directed on your prescription label. Do not take more, take it more often, or use it longer than prescribed. If you are being treated for alcohol withdrawal, follow your doctor’s schedule precisely. Do not share this medication with others. What special precautions should I follow? Before taking chlordiazepoxide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to it or to other benzodiazepines such as alprazolam, clonazepam, clorazepate, diazepam, estazolam, flurazepam, lorazepam, oxazepam, temazepam, or triazolam, and provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use. Your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. Tell your doctor if you have or have ever had glaucoma, seizures, or lung, heart, or liver disease. Tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor right away if you become pregnant while taking this medicine. Adults 65 years or older generally should not take chlordiazepoxide because safer or more effective alternatives may be available. Before any surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you take chlordiazepoxide. This medicine may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. Do not drink alcohol or use street drugs during treatment. What special dietary instructions should I follow? No special dietary restrictions are required. You may take chlordiazepoxide with or without food; taking it with food may reduce stomach upset. Do not drink alcohol. What should I do if I forget a dose? If you take several doses per day and miss a dose, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. Do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. If you are unsure what to do, ask your doctor or pharmacist. What side effects can this medication cause? Common side effects may include drowsiness, dizziness, tiredness, weakness, dry mouth, diarrhea, upset stomach, changes in appetite, restlessness or excitement, constipation, difficulty urinating, frequent urination, blurred vision, and changes in sex drive or ability. Serious side effects can occur. Call your doctor right away or get emergency help if you experience a shuffling walk, persistent fine tremor or inability to sit still, fever, difficulty breathing or swallowing, severe skin rash, yellowing of the skin or eyes, an irregular heartbeat, or any symptoms listed in the Important warning section.

name: Tetrahydrozoline Ophthalmic
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? Tetrahydrozoline ophthalmic is used to temporarily relieve minor eye irritation and redness caused by colds, pollen and other allergens, or exposure such as swimming. How should this medicine be used? Tetrahydrozoline ophthalmic is a liquid eye drop solution. Instill the drops in the affected eye or eyes three to four times daily as needed, or exactly as directed on the package or by your doctor. Do not use more, use less, or use it more often than directed. To apply the drops: Wash your hands well with soap and water. Check the dropper tip to be sure it is not chipped or cracked. Do not touch the dropper tip to your eye or any surface. Tilt your head back and gently pull down the lower eyelid with your index finger to form a pocket. Hold the dropper tip close to the eye without touching it and brace your hand against your face. While looking up, squeeze one drop into the pocket. Release the lower lid. Close your eye for 2 to 3 minutes and tilt your head downward as if looking at the floor. Avoid blinking or squeezing your eyelids. Place a finger on the inner corner of the eye over the tear duct and apply gentle pressure. Wipe away any excess liquid with a tissue. If more than one drop is needed in the same eye, wait at least 5 minutes before the next drop. Replace and tighten the cap; do not wipe or rinse the dropper tip. Wash your hands after use. Other uses for this medicine This medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. What special precautions should I follow? Before using tetrahydrozoline eye drops, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to tetrahydrozoline or any other medications. Tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use, because your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. Tell your doctor if you have any eye disease or infection, heart disease, high blood pressure, or an overactive thyroid. Tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while using the drops, call your doctor. If you are having any surgery, including dental surgery, tell the surgeon or dentist you use tetrahydrozoline eye drops; you may need to stop them temporarily. If you wear soft contact lenses and your product contains benzalkonium chloride, remove lenses before use and wait at least 15 minutes after dosing before reinserting them. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. What should I do if I forget a dose? These drops are usually used as needed. If your doctor has told you to use them on a regular schedule and you miss a dose, use it as soon as you remember. If it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. Do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. What side effects can this medication cause? Tetrahydrozoline eye drops may cause stinging or burning of the eye, blurred vision, or increased eye redness or irritation. If these symptoms are severe or do not go away, contact your doctor. Stop using the drops and call your doctor right away if you experience headache, sweating, fast or irregular heartbeat, or nervousness.

name: Abacavir
instructions: Important warning: Abacavir can cause a serious or life-threatening allergic reaction. Call your doctor immediately if you develop one symptom from two or more of the following groups to see if you should stop taking abacavir: Group 1: fever. Group 2: rash. Group 3: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or stomach-area pain. Group 4: general ill feeling, extreme tiredness, or achiness. Group 5: shortness of breath, cough, or sore throat. Your pharmacist will give you a Warning Card listing these symptoms; carry it with you at all times. Some people are more likely to have this reaction based on inherited factors; your doctor will order a lab test to check your risk. Tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to abacavir or any medication containing abacavir. Do not take this medication if you have ever had an allergic reaction to abacavir or any abacavir-containing product. If your doctor tells you to stop taking abacavir because of an allergic reaction, never take abacavir or an abacavir-containing medication again. If you stop abacavir for any other reason, do not restart it without first talking to your doctor. When you restart, be with people who can provide or call for emergency medical help if needed. Keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory; your doctor will order tests to monitor your response. Your doctor or pharmacist will give you the Medication Guide and a Warning Card when you begin treatment and each time you refill; read them carefully and ask questions. Talk to your doctor about the risks of taking abacavir. Why is this medication prescribed? Abacavir is used to treat human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. It is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that lowers the amount of HIV in the blood. Although it does not cure HIV, it may reduce your chance of developing acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) and HIV-related illnesses. Taking these medications and making other lifestyle changes may also lower the risk of transmitting HIV to others. How should this medicine be used? Abacavir comes as a tablet and an oral solution to take by mouth. It is usually taken once or twice daily, with or without food. Take abacavir at the same times every day and exactly as directed. Do not take more or less, or take it more often than prescribed. Abacavir helps control HIV infection but does not cure it; continue taking it even if you feel well. Do not stop taking abacavir without talking to your doctor. If you stop or skip doses, your condition may become harder to treat, or you could have an allergic reaction when restarting (see Important warning). Other uses for this medicine: Abacavir is also used to prevent HIV infection in people who have been exposed to it; talk to your doctor about the possible risks of using this medication for your situation. This medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. What special precautions should I follow? Before taking abacavir, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this drug, any ingredient in the product, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe the symptoms you had. Tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you for side effects. In addition to the allergy concern noted in the Important warning, tell your doctor if you smoke or if you have or have ever had infections that do not go away or that come and go (such as tuberculosis or cytomegalovirus), depression, diabetes, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, or liver or heart disease. Tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; if you become pregnant while taking abacavir, call your doctor. If you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed, know that abacavir and HIV can pass into breast milk; talk to your doctor about the risks of breastfeeding while taking abacavir. Ask your doctor about the safe use of alcohol while taking this medication. Be aware that as your immune system gets stronger on HIV treatment, it may begin to fight infections that were already in your body (such as pneumonia, herpes viruses, tuberculosis, hepatitis, or fungal infections); report any new symptoms to your doctor. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take the missed dose as soon as you remember. If it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. Do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. If you miss several doses of abacavir, call your doctor before starting it again (see Important warning). What side effects can this medication cause? Abacavir may cause side effects. Common side effects include headache, tiredness, nausea, vomiting, and trouble falling or staying asleep. Some side effects can be serious. If you experience any of the symptoms listed in the Important warning or any of the following, call your doctor immediately: hives; itching; blisters or peeling skin; difficulty swallowing or breathing; excessive tiredness; weakness; dizziness or lightheadedness; fast or irregular heartbeat; muscle pain; stomach pain with nausea and vomiting; shortness of breath; flu-like symptoms such as fever, chills, or cough; feeling cold, especially in the arms or legs; light-colored stools; yellowing of the skin or eyes; loss of appetite; unusual bleeding or bruising; dark yellow or brown urine; or pain in the upper right part of the abdomen. Abacavir may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: Abacavir, Dolutegravir, and Lamivudine
instructions: Important warning: Abacavir, dolutegravir, and lamivudine may cause a serious or life threatening allergic reaction. Call your doctor immediately if you develop at least one symptom from two or more of the following groups: Group 1 fever; Group 2 rash; Group 3 nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or stomach area pain; Group 4 general ill feeling, extreme tiredness, or achiness; Group 5 shortness of breath, cough, or sore throat. Also call your doctor right away if you have headache; muscle or joint pain; swelling of the face, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; pain, burning, or tingling in the hands or feet; itching; blistering or peeling skin; trouble swallowing or breathing; red, swollen, itchy, or teary eyes; or mouth sores. Your pharmacist will give you a Warning Card that lists these symptom groups; carry it with you at all times. Some people are more likely to have an allergic reaction based on their genetic makeup. Your doctor may order a genetic lab test before you start this medicine. Tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to abacavir, dolutegravir, lamivudine, or any abacavir containing medication. If your doctor tells you to stop this medicine because of an allergic reaction, never take it or any other abacavir containing drug again. If you stop this medicine for any other reason, including missing several doses in a row or running out of medication, do not restart it without talking to your doctor first. When you restart, make sure you are around people who can provide or call for emergency medical care if needed. Tell your doctor if you have or think you may have hepatitis B HBV or hepatitis C HCV. If you have HBV and stop this medicine, your liver condition may suddenly worsen. Your doctor will examine you and order lab tests regularly for several months after stopping. Keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. Your doctor will order tests to check how your body responds to this medicine. Your doctor or pharmacist will give you the manufacturer patient information Medication Guide when you begin treatment and each time you refill; read it carefully and ask questions. Talk to your doctor about the risks of taking this medicine. Why is this medication prescribed? The combination of abacavir, dolutegravir, and lamivudine is used to treat HIV infection. Abacavir and lamivudine are nucleoside analogue reverse transcriptase inhibitors NRTIs, and dolutegravir is an integrase strand transfer inhibitor INSTI. They work together to decrease the amount of HIV in your blood and increase the number of immune cells that help fight infections. Although this medicine will not cure HIV, it may lower your chance of developing acquired immunodeficiency syndrome AIDS and HIV related illnesses. Taking this medicine and making other lifestyle changes may reduce the risk of passing HIV to other people. How should this medicine be used? This medicine comes as a tablet to swallow and as tablets for oral suspension that you dissolve in water and take by mouth. Take it once daily with or without food. Take it at the same time every day, exactly as directed. Do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. For tablets for oral suspension, place the tablets in the provided cup with 15 to 20 mL of drinking water 3 tablets can be placed in 15 mL, more than 3 tablets should be placed in 20 mL, then swirl until the tablets are completely dissolved and no lumps remain. After complete dissolution, swallow all the contents within 30 minutes. For children too young to drink from a cup, draw the dissolved medicine into an oral syringe and give it that way. Continue to take this medicine even if you feel well. Do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor. If you stop or skip doses, your condition may become more difficult to treat, or you could have an allergic reaction when restarting see Important warning. Other uses for this medicine This medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. What special precautions should I follow? Before taking this medicine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to abacavir, dolutegravir, lamivudine, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe what symptoms you had. Tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. If you take antacids, laxatives, or multivitamins that contain aluminum, magnesium, or calcium; calcium supplements; iron supplements; sucralfate Carafate; or buffered medicines such as buffered aspirin, take abacavir, dolutegravir, and lamivudine at least 2 hours before or 6 hours after those products. St Johns wort may interact with this medicine; do not take St Johns wort while using this medicine. Tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver disease; your doctor may tell you not to take this medicine. Tell your doctor if you smoke or drink alcohol, or if you have or have ever had high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes, heart disease, or kidney disease. Tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. You will need a pregnancy test before starting treatment, and you should not become pregnant while taking this medicine. Discuss effective birth control methods to use during treatment. If you become pregnant while taking this medicine, call your doctor immediately. Dolutegravir may harm the fetus. Do not breastfeed while taking this medicine because some of the medicine and HIV may pass into breast milk. Ask your doctor about the safe use of alcoholic beverages and products that contain alcohol while you are taking this medicine. Be aware that while you are taking medicines to treat HIV infection, your immune system may get stronger and begin to fight infections already in your body, which may cause new or worsening symptoms. If you develop new or worsening symptoms at any time during treatment, contact your doctor. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. If it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. Do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. What side effects can this medication cause? Abacavir, dolutegravir, and lamivudine may cause side effects. If any of these are severe or do not go away, tell your doctor: trouble falling asleep or staying asleep, headache, tiredness. Some side effects can be serious. If you experience any of the symptoms listed in the Important warning section, or any of the following, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help: excessive tiredness; weakness, dizziness, or lightheadedness; fast or irregular heartbeat; muscle pain; stomach pain with nausea and vomiting; shortness of breath or difficulty breathing; flu like symptoms such as fever, chills, or cough; feeling cold especially in the arms or legs; light colored bowel movements; yellowing of the skin or eyes; loss of appetite; unusual bleeding or bruising; dark yellow or brown urine; or pain in the upper right part of the stomach. This medicine may cause other side effects. If you have any unusual problems while taking it, call your doctor.

name: Abacavir, Lamivudine, and Zidovudine
instructions: Important warning: Abacavir, lamivudine, and zidovudine can cause a serious or life-threatening allergic reaction. Call your doctor right away if you develop one symptom from two or more of these groups: Group 1: fever. Group 2: rash. Group 3: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or stomach-area pain. Group 4: generally ill feeling, extreme tiredness, or achiness. Group 5: shortness of breath, cough, or sore throat. Your pharmacist will give you a Warning Card listing these symptoms each time you receive your medication—carry it with you at all times. Some people are more likely to have an allergic reaction based on their genetic makeup; your doctor may order a genetic lab test before starting treatment. Tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to abacavir or any medication containing abacavir. If your doctor tells you to stop because of an allergic reaction, never take abacavir, lamivudine, and zidovudine or any medicine containing abacavir again. If you stop this medicine for any other reason, including missing several doses or running out, do not restart without first talking to your doctor. When you restart, be around people who can call for emergency help if needed. This medicine can reduce your body’s ability to make blood cells; tell your doctor if you have or have ever had low blood counts or blood disorders. Call your doctor immediately if you have unusual bleeding or bruising, shortness of breath, pale skin, fever, sore throat, chills, other signs of infection, or unusual tiredness or weakness. This medicine may cause muscle problems; tell your doctor if you have or have ever had muscle disease or swelling. Call your doctor right away if you develop muscle pain or weakness. This medicine can cause life-threatening liver damage; tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver disease. If you have liver disease, your doctor may tell you not to take it. Seek immediate medical care for nausea, vomiting, pain in the upper right abdomen, loss of appetite, flu-like symptoms, extreme tiredness, unusual bleeding or bruising, weakness, dizziness, lightheadedness, fast or irregular heartbeat, trouble breathing, dark yellow or brown urine, pale stools, yellowing of the skin or eyes, feeling cold (especially in the arms or legs), or new or different muscle pain. This medicine does not treat hepatitis B virus (HBV). Your doctor may test you for HBV before starting. If you have HBV and take this medicine, your condition may suddenly worsen when you stop. Your doctor will examine you and order lab tests regularly for several months after stopping. Keep all appointments. Your doctor may order tests to check your response to treatment. You will receive a Medication Guide when you start and with each refill; read it and ask your doctor or pharmacist any questions. Talk to your doctor about the risks of taking this medicine. Why is this medication prescribed? The combination of abacavir, lamivudine, and zidovudine is used to treat human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. These medicines are nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) that lower the amount of HIV in the blood. Although not a cure, they may reduce your chance of developing acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) and HIV-related illnesses. Taking these medications as directed, along with other preventive measures, may decrease the risk of transmitting HIV to others. How should this medicine be used? Abacavir, lamivudine, and zidovudine comes as a tablet taken by mouth, with or without food, usually twice daily. Take it at the same times each day. Take exactly as prescribed—do not take more or less or more often than directed. Continue even if you feel well. Do not stop without talking to your doctor. Stopping or skipping doses can make your condition harder to treat and can trigger a dangerous allergic reaction when restarting (see Important warning). What special precautions should I follow? Before taking this medicine, tell your doctor and pharmacist about any allergy to this drug, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe what symptoms you had. Tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you for side effects. Tell your doctor if you smoke or drink alcohol, or if you have or have ever had any condition mentioned in the Important warning section, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes, heart disease, or kidney disease. Tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking this medicine. Do not breastfeed because some of the medication and HIV may pass into breast milk; discuss the risks with your doctor. Be aware that body fat may increase or move to your upper back and neck (“buffalo hump”), breasts, and abdomen, and you may lose fat from your face, legs, and arms. While treating HIV, your immune system may get stronger and start to fight infections already in your body, causing new or worsening symptoms; report any new or worsening symptoms to your doctor right away. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take the missed dose as soon as you remember. If it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. Do not take two doses at once. What side effects can this medication cause? This medicine may cause side effects. Common effects include anxiety, depression, and headache. Some side effects can be serious—see the Important warning section and call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care if they occur. This medicine may cause other side effects; if you have any unusual problems while taking it, contact your doctor.
